Express
Suisse Secrets: leak reveals how Credit Suisse accepted many millions of euros in dirty money
An investigation carried out by more than 160 journalists in 39 countries based on a leak shared by the German newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung shows how, over the years, Credit Suisse opened and maintained secret accounts controlled by corrupt politicians, dictators, drug traffickers and other criminals
Facebook
Twitter
Linkedin
email
17:02 February 20, 2022
18:37 February 20, 2022
|
Micael Pereira and OCCRP
It was a close call that António Horta-Osório, the Portuguese banker who was forced to resign a month ago as chairman of Credit Suisse, after admitting that he violated the mandatory quarantine imposed by anti-Covid restrictions on trips to the United Kingdom, did not have to deal with a new headache for what is Switzerland's second largest bank. A massive leak from Credit Suisse with details about almost 100 billion euros deposited in 18,000 bank accounts of 30,000 clients, including individuals and companies, shows how the bank hid the fortunes of dozens of unsavory clients spread across the world, involved in cases of torture, drug trafficking, corruption, money laundering schemes and other crimes.
Among Credit Suisse's most dubious clients are some individuals convicted in court who, even then, managed to open or maintain accounts at the bank.
The information leak was delivered almost a year ago to the Süddeutsche Zeitung, one of the largest German newspapers, the same one that obtained the Panama Papers files, and was shared with an investigative journalism consortium, the
OCCRP (Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project)
, and 46 other media outlets in 39 countries, including Expresso in Portugal,
the Guardian
in the United Kingdom, Le Monde in France and the New York Times in the United States.
More than 160 journalists came together to investigate, over the course of months, the data shared by the Süddeutsche Zeitung, focusing on the cases of the most problematic clients, in which the way Credit Suisse has dealt with verifying who its clients are and the criteria it has applied to accept and maintain their accounts may be at stake, including the lack of scrutiny regarding the origin of the fortunes that are deposited there and the profile of the holders of these fortunes.
Photo: Getty Images
Among the dubious clients are, for example, the financial advisor of the former Egyptian dictator Hosni Mubarak and his head of the secret services, Omar Suleiman, responsible for many human rights violations; General Khaled Nezzar, former Minister of Defense and leader of a military junta in Algeria who is on trial in Switzerland for war crimes and crimes against humanity; or a cocaine trafficking network in Bulgaria that is also on trial, in which the bank is accused of having helped in the money laundering scheme, by allowing this criminal organization to operate dozens of bank accounts and eight safes between 2004 and 2007.
The list also includes Venezuelan officials and politicians involved in corrupt payments related to the state oil company PDVSA — and whose names are known in Portugal, as is the case of Nervis Villalobos, former deputy minister of Energy under Hugo Chávez, who has been investigated in Spain, the United States and also in a criminal case that the DCIAP (Central Department of Investigation and Criminal Action) has underway regarding alleged bribes paid by the Espírito Santo Group in Venezuela.
In relation to Portugal,
Credit Suisse maintained dozens of accounts for Portuguese-Angolan Álvaro Sobrinho, former president of Banco Espírito Santo Angola (BESA), and for Hélder Bataglia, president of Escom and former administrator of BESA
, some of them after the criminal investigations that have been taking place in Lisbon since 2011 related to these clients were made public.
António Horta-Osório, the Portuguese banker who was recently forced to resign as chairman of Credit Suisse Photo: BEN STANSALL/AFP via Getty Images
Several Angolans were also identified as problematic. José Filomeno dos Santos, the son of former president José Eduardo dos Santos who was at the head of the Angolan Sovereign Fund. Filomeno opened an account with Credit Suisse in 2008, which reached 18 million Swiss francs the following year, despite the fact that at that time he was still taking his first steps as an entrepreneur. The account was closed in 2013. The son of the former head of state was sentenced to five years in prison in 2020, for crimes of fraud, embezzlement and influence peddling, regarding a transfer of 500 million dollars of public funds originating from the National Bank of Angola.
In addition to Zenu, it was possible to identify in Suisse Secrets the current president of the Angola Stock Exchange, António Gomes Furtado, who had two accounts at the bank between 1998 and 2013, one of them with almost five million euros, when he was an employee of the National Bank of Angola, where he became part of the audit board. Neither José Filomeno dos Santos nor António Gomes Furtado responded to requests for comment sent by Expresso, OCCRP and Süddeutsche Zeitung.
Bank says it complies with the law
In a short and generic response to a series of detailed questions that were sent by media partners in the investigation, Credit Suisse says that the bank “operates in compliance with all applicable global and local laws and regulations”, highlighting that “a series of important measures in the context of Swiss financial reforms” have been implemented in recent years. “Considerable investments have been made in compliance and the fight against financial crime.”
At Suisse Secrets there are accounts opened in the 1940s, although more than two thirds were created after 2000, with many still operational in the last decade. The investigation revealed that around 200 of these accounts had balances of 100 million Swiss francs or more. And a dozen surpass the billion mark.
These numbers represent less than 1% of Credit Suisse's asset and client portfolio, which is ranked in financial industry rankings as the 41st largest bank in the world. In total, the institution manages more than 1.5 billion euros, has more than 1.6 million customers and employs almost 50 thousand employees.
The accounts of more than fifty customers identified as problematic by the project's journalists accumulated almost eight billion euros, considering the sum of their maximum balances.
For the source of the information leak that sent this data to the Süddeutsche Zeitung, “Swiss bank secrecy laws are immoral” and “the pretext of protecting financial privacy is just a fig leaf that covers the shameful role of Swiss banks as collaborators of tax evaders”.
Swiss banking secrecy, one of the strongest and most famous in the world, because it can lead to people being arrested if they share confidential information about clients and accounts, became law in 1934. Its high level of secrecy was justified at the time by the need to protect the assets of Jewish clients during the Nazi regime, but this opacity began to allow many clients wanting to hide dirty money to seek to open accounts in Zurich or Geneva.
In the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis and growing pressure around tax avoidance and how this has been affecting the ability of many states to generate sufficient public revenue to cover the costs of education and healthcare for their populations, Switzerland ended up embracing the automatic exchange of information between tax administrations. Since 2018, Swiss banks have participated in this exchange of information, through a system known as CRS (Common Reporting Standard).
The Association of Swiss Banks has promoted the idea that adherence to this information-sharing regime means that the era of confidentiality is over and a new era of transparency has begun.
However, while this is true for customers in developed countries, such as Portugal, it is still not true for the more than 90 developing nations that have been left out. The CRS system “imposes a disproportionate financial burden on developing nations, perpetuating their exclusion from the system for the foreseeable future”, says the Suisse Secrets whistleblower. "This situation allows corruption and starves developing countries, for which tax revenues are very necessary. These countries are, therefore, the ones that suffer most from Switzerland's ability to be a reverse Robin Hood."
The business of taking money from the poor
In recent decades, examples have accumulated of how Credit Suisse has contributed to these financial acrobatics, helping to steal from the poor so that the rich can accumulate often astronomical levels of wealth.
One of the most notorious cases was that of former Philippine dictator Ferdinando Marcos and his now widowed wife, Imelda Marcos. In the 1990s, ten years after Ferdinando ceased to be president of the Philippines, a court forced Credit Suisse to return hundreds of millions of dollars to that country's public coffers.
Archive image of President Ferdinando Marcos and his wife, Imelda Marcos, in 1986. Photo: Melvyn Calderon / Liaison Agency
Suisse Secrets include an account that a lawyer, Helen Rivilla, managed to open with Credit Suisse in 2000, despite being convicted in 1992 of helping the Philippine dictator launder money.
There are numerous situations in the data in which the bank appears to have ignored the compromising information that was circulating publicly about its customers.
Two months after becoming Prime Minister of Ukraine, in 1998, Pavlo Lazarenko became a client at Credit Suisse, accumulating more than seven million euros in his accounts, despite his humble origins and having always worked only in public functions. Later, in 2006, he was sentenced in the United States to nine years in prison for being corrupted by a Ukrainian businessman.
“People shouldn't have access to the system if the money they have is corrupt money,” says Graham Barrow, an independent financial crimes expert interviewed by OCCRP. “The bank has a clear duty to ensure that the funds it manages have a clear and legitimate origin.”
The problem is not restricted to Credit Suisse, because other important banks have been involved in scandals of this type. “The irony is that Switzerland has become the place for dirty money to go because it is pure, well managed, reliable,” admits James Henry, a senior adviser at the Tax Justice Network, a non-governmental organization in the UK, who has studied tax evasion schemes at Credit Suisse. “The problem is this business model of taking money from poor countries.”
Suisse Secrets shows how the bank's compliance department also appears to have clearly failed when a Swede, Stefan Sederholm, opened an account in 2008 and managed to keep it open for five years. Although it was reported in 2009 that Sederholm was exploiting girls in Thailand to sell sexual services, and he was sentenced to life in prison for human trafficking in 2011, it was only in 2013 that the bank took action and terminated him as a customer. Or when an Egyptian billionaire, Hisham Talaat Moustafa, was convicted in 2008 for the murder of his girlfriend, but had his account operating until 2014. Or even when Ronald Li Fook-shiu, despite being sentenced to prison in 1990 for receiving bribes while president of the Hong Kong stock exchange, was accepted as a client a decade later, having accumulated almost 60 million euros at Credit Suisse.
In its response, the bank assures that the cases it was confronted by journalists belong to the past. “As a world-leading financial institution, Credit Suisse is deeply aware of its responsibility to clients and the financial system as a whole to ensure that the highest standards of conduct are maintained.”
Encourage ignorance
However, more than a dozen current and former employees interviewed by OCCRP in recent months portray a “highly toxic” work culture that encourages risk-taking to make more profits. The bonuses that employees receive are associated with the entry of fresh money into the institution.
“The bank encourages a bank manager to look the other way when faced with an account that he knows is toxic,” a long-time Credit Suisse executive confesses to OCCRP. "If you close a toxic account, especially a large account with more than 20 million dollars, the bank manager finds himself in a big hole. A hole that is almost impossible to get out of."
Maintaining a job may depend on how large accounts are managed, in which there actually seem to be two types of rules: those that serve ordinary clients and those that are reserved only for the richest.
“Due diligence on clients and accounts — say, at a level up to a million dollars — is very thorough,” explains a former employee. “But when it comes to high net worth accounts, bosses encourage everyone to look the other way and managers feel intimidated because of their bonuses and job security.”
Credit Suisse Building, London Photo: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images
The testimonies collected give an idea of how cynical and easy to maneuver the system has become. “The bank’s compliance department is a master of plausible deniability,” a former Credit Suisse account manager in Zurich tells OCCRP. “Never ask a question you don’t want to know the answer to.” Ignorance is encouraged.
If the clients are very special, but also very problematic, it is best to avoid the usual routes. “Large account holders go directly to top managers, and do not go through the normal private banking system,” explains an executive. "The type of people the bank attracts are mercenaries and they all seek to enrich themselves first, probably understanding that there is no real relationship with the bank. You are only there as long as you make money, regardless of how you make that money," adds a former employee.
The case of the Bulgarian trafficking network that has been tried is a clear example of how far things can go. It is the first time in Switzerland that a Swiss bank is sitting as a defendant. According to the indictment, Credit Suisse allowed traffickers to launder more than nine million euros from the sale of cocaine.
Prosecutors accuse the bank's managers of having ignored clear signs that existed about customers and the illicit origin of their fortune, including the fact that they deposited bags of cash. Even after one of the criminals was murdered and this death was reported in the newspapers as being linked to cocaine trafficking, the accounts were not cancelled. One of the managers involved with these clients admitted in court that the bank taught her everything about the importance of Swiss banking secrecy. But very little about how to check the suitability of your clients.

title: Papa critica povos que se dizem cristãos e pensam fazer a guerra
original_title: Papa critica povos que se dizem cristãos e pensam fazer a guerra - Renascença
translated_title: Pope criticizes people who call themselves Christians and think of waging war - Renascença
original_text:
Em Destaque
Em direto. Moreirense - FC Porto
Putin e Macron acordam trabalhar para alcançar cessar-fogo no leste

PS acusa PSD de "irresponsabilidade e insensibilidade" para com emigrantes

​“Putin terrorista!” Dezenas de ucranianos manifestam-se em Lisboa
A+
/
A-
Papa critica povos que se dizem cristãos e pensam fazer a guerra
20 fev, 2022 - 12:20 •
Aura Miguel
,
Inês Rocha
Papa lembrou que a atitude cristã é a de "dar a outra face", ou seja, "vencer o mal com o bem", "desarmar o rancor".
A+
/
A-
Foto: Giuseppe Lami/EPA
O Papa Francisco criticou, este domingo, no Vaticano, as “pessoas e povos orgulhosos de serem cristãos” que pensam em “fazer guerra”.
“Com o Espírito de Jesus podemos responder ao mal com o bem, podemos amar quem nos faz mal. Assim fazem os cristãos. Como é triste quando pessoas e povos orgulhosos de serem cristãos veem os outros como inimigos e pensam em fazer guerra!”, disse o Papa, antes a recitação da oração do Ângelus.
Este domingo, Francisco nunca se referiu diretamente ao conflito que parece iminente entre a Rússia e a Ucrânia. Papa refletiu antes sobre o Evangelho em que Jesus diz aos seus discípulos para oferecer a “outra face”, para “desarmar o rancor”.
“Dar a outra face não significa sofrer em silêncio, ceder à injustiça. Jesus denuncia o que é injusto, mas fá-lo sem raiva nem violência, mas com bondade. Ele não quer desencadear uma discussão, mas desarmar o rancor: extinguir o ódio e a injustiça, tentando recuperar o irmão culpado. Isso é dar a outra face: a mansidão de Jesus é uma resposta mais forte do que o golpe que recebeu”, afirmou o Papa, perante milhares de fiéis reunidos na praça de São Pedro.
“Dar a outra face não é o recuo de quem perde, mas a ação de quem tem uma força interior maior, que vence o mal com o bem, que abre uma brecha no coração do inimigo, desmascarando o absurdo de seu ódio. Não é ditado pelo cálculo, mas pelo amor”, continuou.
Papa lembra “heroicidade” dos profissionais de saúde
Depois da recitação do Ângelus, Francisco lembrou as populações vítimas das
inundações em Madagascar
e
Petrópolis, no Brasil.
No dia nacional do profissional de saúde em Itália, o Papa fez também uma homenagem a estes profissionais, que apelidou de “heróis”.
“Devemos recordar tantos médicos, enfermeiros e enfermeiras, voluntários que estão próximo dos doentes, cuidam deles, fazem-nos sentir-se melhor e que os ajudam: o heróico pessoal de saúde que nos mostrou esta heroicidade durante o Covid, mas cuja heroicidade permanece todos os dias. Aos nossos médicos, enfermeiros e enfermeiras e voluntários, um aplauso e um grande obrigado”, disse o Papa, no Vaticano.

Pope criticizes people who call themselves Christians and think of waging war
Feb 20, 2022 - 12:20 •
Aura Miguel
,
Ines Rocha
Pope recalled that the Christian attitude is to "turn the other cheek", that is, "overcome evil with good", "disarm resentment".
A+
/
A-
Photo: Giuseppe Lami/EPA
Pope Francis criticized, this Sunday, in the Vatican, the “people and people who are proud to be Christians” who think about “waging war”.
"With the Spirit of Jesus we can respond to evil with good, we can love those who do us harm. That's what Christians do. How sad it is when people and peoples who are proud to be Christians see others as enemies and think about waging war!", said the Pope, before reciting the Angelus prayer.
This Sunday, Francis never directly referred to the conflict that appears imminent between Russia and Ukraine. Pope previously reflected on the Gospel in which Jesus tells his disciples to turn the “other cheek”, to “disarm resentment”.
"To turn the other cheek does not mean to suffer in silence, to give in to injustice. Jesus denounces what is unjust, but he does so without anger or violence, but with kindness. He does not want to trigger an argument, but to disarm resentment: to extinguish hatred and injustice, trying to recover the guilty brother. This is to turn the other cheek: Jesus' meekness is a stronger response than the blow he received", said the Pope, before thousands of faithful gathered in St. Peter's Square.
"Turning the other cheek is not the retreat of those who lose, but the action of those who have greater inner strength, who overcome evil with good, who open a breach in the heart of the enemy, unmasking the absurdity of their hatred. It is not dictated by calculation, but by love", he continued.
Pope remembers “heroicity” of health professionals
After the recitation of the Angelus, Francisco reminded the populations that were victims of
floods in Madagascar
and
Petrópolis, in Brazil.
On the national day of healthcare professionals in Italy, the Pope also paid tribute to these professionals, whom he called “heroes”.
"We must remember so many doctors, nurses and nurses, volunteers who are close to the sick, care for them, make them feel better and who help them: the heroic healthcare personnel who showed us this heroicity during Covid, but whose heroics remain every day. To our doctors, nurses and volunteers, an applause and a big thank you", said the Pope, in the Vatican.

title: Cardeal António Marto apelou em Fátima à orao pela paz na Ucrânia
original_title: Cardeal António Marto apelou em Fátima à oração pela paz na Ucrânia – Região de Leiria
translated_title: Cardinal António Marto appealed in Fátima to pray for peace in Ukraine – Leiria Region
original_text:
Sociedade
Cardeal António Marto apelou em Fátima à oração pela paz na Ucrânia
O bispo de Leiria-Fátima manifestou este domingo preocupação com a atual situação de crise no Leste da Europa.
António Marto presidiu este domingo às celebrações da festa litúrgica dos santos Francisco e Jacinta Marto SANTUÁRIO DE FÁTIMA
O cardeal António Marto apelou este domingo em Fátima à oração pela paz na Ucrânia.
O bispo da Diocese de Leiria-Fátima dirigiu-se aos peregrinos durante a festa litúrgica dos santos Francisco e Jacinta Marto e “a todos os católicos do país” para iniciarem  “uma corrente de oração do rosário nesta semana, em forma individual, familiar ou comunitária, pela paz na Ucrânia”.
Na última celebração a que presidiu no Santuário de Fátima enquanto titular da diocese,
António Marto
evocou o “contexto atual que o mundo conhece e atravessa, após longo período de fragilidades, feridas, incertezas, luto e medos em que paira uma ameaça de guerra”.
“É necessário despertar da indiferença, da apatia, do cansaço espiritual, do desânimo que pode levar ao fatalismo”, sustentou, alertando ainda para a necessidade de contrariar a ideia de que “só os poderosos – os poderes económico-financeiros e políticos – podem transformar o mundo”, de acordo com uma nota de imprensa do Santuário,
“Deus conta com os pequenos e os humildes, com a força da fé na sua misericórdia, com o testemunho da conversão e da compaixão, com a força da oração para renovar o mundo. Somos chamados a olhar o futuro com confiança, reconstruindo as relações entre as pessoas e os povos, como Bons Samaritanos que cuidam dos feridos e ajudam a curar as feridas do nosso tempo”, disse ainda, reforçando a sua preocupação com a atual situação de crise no Leste da Europa.
“A pandemia ainda não passou e deixou marcas, e hoje por exemplo tivemos aqui uma multidão de peregrinos que veio e refletiu sobre a infância, que é por si atrativa, num mundo ferido e cheio de divisões e violência, as pessoas buscam a inocência, que trazem dentro de si desde os tempos de criança como aspiração, a confiança na beleza e na bondade da vida, e a aspiração pela paz, num momento tão difícil e tão duro para o mundo, pois estamos a viver algo que nunca imaginamos, depois da 2.ª Guerra Mundial, e espero bem que os homens possam refletir na sua consciência e ver os passos que devem evitar para não fazer sofrer a humanidade”, acrescentou, citado pelo Santuário.
António Marto, que cessa funções como bispo de Leiria-Fátima a 6 de março, irá residir no Santuário como bispo emérito, sendo substituído a 13 de março por
José Ornelas, atual bispo de Setúbal
e presidente da Conferência Episcopal.
“Dedicar-me-ei ao ministério da oração e da intercessão pela paz no mundo, ao atendimento espiritual das pessoas, ao sacramento da reconciliação, ao estudo da teologia, que é sempre uma paixão”, disse hoje o cardeal aos jornalistas.

translated_text:
Society
Cardinal António Marto appealed in Fátima to pray for peace in Ukraine
The bishop of Leiria-Fátima expressed concern this Sunday about the current crisis situation in Eastern Europe.
António Marto presided this Sunday at the celebrations of the liturgical feast of Saints Francisco and Jacinta Marto SANTUÁRIO DE FÁTIMA
Cardinal António Marto called this Sunday in Fátima to pray for peace in Ukraine.
The bishop of the Diocese of Leiria-Fátima addressed the pilgrims during the liturgical feast of Saints Francisco and Jacinta Marto and “all Catholics in the country” to start “a rosary prayer chain this week, in individual, family or community form, for peace in Ukraine”.
In the last celebration he presided over at the Sanctuary of Fátima as head of the diocese,
Antonio Marto
evoked the “current context that the world knows and is going through, after a long period of fragility, wounds, uncertainty, mourning and fears in which there is a threat of war”.
“It is necessary to awaken from indifference, apathy, spiritual fatigue, discouragement that can lead to fatalism”, he maintained, also warning of the need to counter the idea that “only the powerful – the economic-financial and political powers – can transform the world”, according to a press release from the Sanctuary,
"God counts on the small and the humble, on the strength of faith in his mercy, on the testimony of conversion and compassion, on the strength of prayer to renew the world. We are called to look to the future with confidence, rebuilding relationships between people and peoples, as Good Samaritans who care for the wounded and help heal the wounds of our time", he also said, reinforcing his concern with the current crisis situation in Eastern Europe.
“The pandemic has not yet passed and left its mark, and today, for example, we had a crowd of pilgrims here who came and reflected on childhood, which is attractive in itself, in a wounded world full of divisions and violence, people seek innocence, which they have carried within themselves since childhood as an aspiration, confidence in the beauty and goodness of life, and the aspiration for peace, in such a difficult and difficult time for the world, as we are experiencing something we never imagined, after the Second World War World Cup, and I hope that men can reflect on their conscience and see the steps they must avoid in order not to make humanity suffer”, he added, quoted by the Sanctuary.
António Marto, who ceases his duties as bishop of Leiria-Fátima on March 6th, will reside in the Sanctuary as bishop emeritus, being replaced on March 13th by
José Ornelas, current bishop of Setúbal
and president of the Episcopal Conference.
“I will dedicate myself to the ministry of prayer and intercession for peace in the world, to the spiritual care of people, to the sacrament of reconciliation, to the study of theology, which is always a passion,” the cardinal told journalists today.

Cardinal Antû°nio Marto today, in FûÀtima, urged Portuguese Catholics to pray for peace in Ukraine, stressing that, in the face of the threat of war, "it is necessary to awaken from indifference".
In the last mass that, as apostolic administrator of the diocese of Leiria-FûÀtima, he presided at the SantuûÀrio de FûÀtima, Antû°nio Marto warned of the "current context that the world knows and is going through, after a long period of fragility, wounds, uncertainties, mourning and fears, in which there is a threat of war is necessary to awaken from indifference, apathy, spiritual fatigue, discouragement that can lead to fatalism".
"Sometimes we are led to think that only the powerful - the economic-financial and political powers - can transform the world. But God counts on the small and the humble, on the strength of faith in his mercy, on the testimony of conversion and compassion, on the strength of prayer to renew the world. We are called to look to the future with confidence, rebuilding relationships between people and peoples, as Good Samaritans who care for the wounded and help heal the wounds of our time", added the cardinal in his homily.
"From this Sanctuary of Peace, I appeal to you present here and to all Catholics in the country to start a rosary prayer chain this week, in individual, family or community form, for peace in Ukraine", urged Antû°nio Marto, who on the next day On March 13, he will be replaced in the leadership of the diocese by Josûˋ Ornelas, until now Bishop of Setû¤bal and current president of the Portuguese Episcopal Conference.
Today's celebration marked the liturgical solemnity of Saints Francisco and Jacinta Marto, visionaries of FûÀtima, with Antû°nio Marto considering that they "are the best living commentary on the proclaimed gospel".
Francisco and Jacinta, according to the cardinal, "in moments of great suffering from wars and persecution", offered themselves "without hesitation, with their total yes, with the burning love they had in their chest, with the solidary prayer of the rosary, with small and large sacrifices, with the testimony of fidelity until the end of the His entire life was an oblation, for peace in the world and the conversion of poor sinners most in need of mercy."
In statements at the end of the mass, cited by the Press Room of the SantuûÀrio, Antû°nio Marto recalled May 13, 2017 as "the most fulfilling and remarkable moment" while he was at the head of the diocese of Leiria-FûÀtima, as "it was a culminating moment of the entire Centenary of ApariûÏûçes, with the arrival of the Pope, the canonization of the Little Shepherds and the arrival of millions of pilgrims from all over the world".
The prelate also recalled the 13th of May 2020, in the middle of the pandemic, in which he presided over "a pilgrimage that I never imagined, spiritual, with a Sanctuary without pilgrims (...), it was touching".
Cardinal Antû°nio Marto, who now becomes bishop emûˋrito, joining Serafim Ferreira da Silva, who already holds that title, entered Leiria on June 25, 2006.

title: Os melhores cartoons em exposio no Museu do Vinho Bairrada
original_title: Os melhores cartoons em exposição no Museu do Vinho Bairrada – Jornal da Bairrada
translated_title: The best cartoons on display at the Bairrada Wine Museum – Jornal da Bairrada
original_text:
Anadia
//
Sociedade
Os melhores cartoons em exposição no Museu do Vinho Bairrada
As duas exposições temporárias podem ser visitadas até ao dia 30 de abril
O Museu do Vinho Bairrada, em Anadia, tem patente ao público um novo núcleo expositivo temporário, “XXIII PortoCartoon – World Festival” e “Pablo Picasso visto pela Caricatura Internacional”, onde dá a conhecer o que de melhor se faz, a nível mundial, na arte do Cartoon.
Esta instalação é composta por mais de 200 trabalhos. A pandemia de Covid-19, as alterações climáticas, a saúde e os conflitos são alguns dos temas abordados nesta mostra, que se apresenta como uma “vacina de humor”.
O “XXIII PortoCartoon – World Festival” apresenta os melhores trabalhos selecionados pelo Júri internacional, designadamente a obra do artista brasileiro Cau Gomez, intitulada “A Peste”, que conquistou o Grande Prémio. Uma metáfora de humor negro sobre as ameaças do tempo presente e os cordelinhos do fenómeno.
A mostra “Pablo Picasso visto pela Caricatura Internacional” desconstrói o genial e imortal pintor espanhol, destacando a sua emblemática obra “Guernica”, símbolo de piedade e terror. Neste âmbito, estão patentes mais de setenta trabalhos de artistas de trinta países, entre os quais a Bulgária, Brasil, Colômbia, Costa Rica, Escócia, Egipto, Índia, Montenegro, Polónia, Roménia, Sérvia, Suécia e Ucrânia, além de Portugal. Esta exposição apresenta também um conjunto de livros sobre a vida e obra de Picasso.
Estas exposições, que resultam de uma parceria entre o Município de Anadia e o Museu Nacional da Imprensa, podem ser visitadas até ao dia 30 de abril, durante o horário de funcionamento do Museu: terça a sexta-feira, das 10h às 13h e das 14h às 18h; sábado, domingo e feriados, das 11h às 19h.
translated_text:
Anadia
//
Society
The best cartoons on display at the Bairrada Wine Museum
The two temporary exhibitions can be visited until April 30th
The Bairrada Wine Museum, in Anadia, has a new temporary exhibition center open to the public, “XXIII PortoCartoon – World Festival” and “Pablo Picasso seen by International Caricature”, which showcases the best that is done, worldwide, in the art of Cartoon.
This installation is made up of more than 200 works. The Covid-19 pandemic, climate change, health and conflicts are some of the topics covered in this exhibition, which presents itself as a “humor vaccine”.
The “XXIII PortoCartoon – World Festival” presents the best works selected by the international Jury, namely the work by Brazilian artist Cau Gomez, entitled “The Plague”, which won the Grand Prize. A darkly humorous metaphor about the threats of the present time and the strings attached to the phenomenon.
The exhibition “Pablo Picasso seen by International Caricature” deconstructs the brilliant and immortal Spanish painter, highlighting his emblematic work “Guernica”, a symbol of piety and terror. In this context, more than seventy works by artists from thirty countries are on display, including Bulgaria, Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Scotland, Egypt, India, Montenegro, Poland, Romania, Serbia, Sweden and Ukraine, in addition to Portugal. This exhibition also presents a set of books about Picasso's life and work.
These exhibitions, which are the result of a partnership between the Municipality of Anadia and the National Press Museum, can be visited until April 30th, during the Museum's opening hours: Tuesday to Friday, from 10am to 1pm and from 2pm to 6pm; Saturday, Sunday and holidays, from 11am to 7pm.
